question: Will you have a mask policy

answers.description: This is NOT recommended.
You will need to put this policy in writing and share it broadly (see messaging below). You will also need enforcement guidelines, including consequences and escalation steps.

You will need to have your policy reviewed by your legal team. You will also need to add language for medical exemptions – these ought to be rare, so the conditions that are acceptable may need to be explicitly listed, and medical documentation can be required. You will also need to be able to provide back-up masks (see supplies below). You will need a list of what is considered an appropriate mask (i.e., will face shields be acceptable? Must they cover the nose? Fabric thickness? Gaping?)

Your policy should still encourage mask use strongly. You may need to negotiate with your teachers /staff/building custodians/union as to whether individual teachers may require masks in their classrooms.

If teachers are to be responsible for enforcing mask policies, they must be given resources and authority to do so. They should be educated on the proper wearing and removal of masks and given age-appropriate curricula for teaching their students. Information for students should be posted in classrooms. Students and teachers should be provided with an approved list of times when masks can be removed. Teachers should be provided with a list of students with exemptions. Students should also be informed of the consequences for refusal to wear a mask or for tampering with another’s mask, and when to escalate situations related to mask-wearing.
There will need to be monitors in charge of checking for mask wearing in hallways.
Recess monitors will need to be taught to observe mask wearing. There will need to be a supply of masks in the recess area for those that become dirty, wet, or broken.

It is not possible to eat with a mask on, so cafeteria rules will need to include when masks may be removed and where they should be placed during eating. Providing each student with a napkin or paper towel to place their mask on may be the simplest approach, but messaging should include signs showing when masks can be removed, how to take the mask off safely, and where to put it to avoid cross-contamination.

If possible, mask policies should extend to all school activities. Extracurricular leaders should be given the same instruction as teachers on mask wearing and safe removal. Consequences for failure to wear masks in extracurricular activities should be transparent and shared widely.

It may not be safe for those participating in contact sports to wear masks. If this is the case, clear guidelines should be made for each sport as to the times when masks should and should not be worn, with a preference for mask wearing as much as possible. These sports will also require a safe place to put masks when they are not being worn, and supervision to ensure that tampering and mask swapping do not occur.

question: How will you share your policy with the members of your staff

answers.description: These will need to make clear all aspects of the policy, including the full text.
These should be virtual if possible, and should include a question and answer period.

These may be needed periodically. Ideally they should be scheduled for regular intervals, such as at scheduled staff meetings or through weekly emails. You may also want to have reminders ready in case issues arise, such as complaints about compliance.

question: How will you inform parents of your policy

answers.description: While this should include the full text, you will also need to lead with a simplified explanation that can be read easily on mobile devices.
Be sure to cover all aspects of the policy, including consequences, exceptions, and the exemption process.
These should include diagrams on how masks should be worn, lists of acceptable mask types, information on the exemption process, and a list of consequences for compliance issues.
These may be needed periodically but would most likely be reserved for when issues arise. They should be neutral in tone, avoid blame, and use positive, encouraging language.

question: How will you teach students about mask-wearing

answers.description: This should be age-appropriate and science-based. At all levels, it should cover proper wearing of the mask, how to remove safely, and washing. At upper levels, it could involve discussion of airborne particles in a physics or earth sciences course, the mechanics of breathing in a biology course, the historical use of masks for infectious disease control in a history course, or the design of masks in an art or home economics course, among other topics.

School announcement times are a good opportunity to remind students about mask wearing. These can be creative and fun – this would be a way to engage students and could include (supervised) student-led writing.
These signs should indicate the basics as simply as possible, and should be posted at every entrance.
These should be reminder signs and can be more creative and fun. A sign design competition could be used to create interest and engage students.
These should be reminders and should be targeted towards the age and subject. Individual teachers may want to design their own signs.
These signs should indicate when and how to remove masks for eating.
Any area that people within the school will regularly use should have a sign. This could include a teacher’s lounge, gym and weight room, or auditorium, for example.

question: How will you provide masks
description: You should have, at minimum, a small supply of masks for when masks break, get wet, or get dirty. You may want to provide more.

answers.description: Basic disposable masks can be bought in bulk now. These should not be reused.

Reusable masks reduce waste but are more expensive. It might be possible to have a mask drive to collect a supply of masks. If this is done, all masks should be washed before being provided to students or staff.

This is the minimum necessary. You should have a process for getting a mask when needed, and it might be necessary to have a supply available at the doors at entrance times, in case of forgotten masks, and in recess and gym areas, in case of broken or dirty masks.

If you wish to supply masks to all students, you will need to source enough to provide each student with at least 2, and preferably 5, reusable masks or sufficient disposable masks for a new mask to be worn every day.

If you do wish to supply masks to all teachers or staff, you should source enough to provide at least 2, preferably 5, reusable masks or sufficient disposable masks for a new mask to be worn every day.

As clear masks might be needed for certain teachers or staff (kindergarten, dual language or language, speech pathologists), you will need a supply of these. Be sure that they are snug to the face in the areas around the mouth and nose. Please note that face shields are sufficient for short face-to-face encounters only and are not protective in long-term indoor interactions such as classrooms.

question: What mask disposal methods will you have
description: Mask disposal will be a larger problem if you provide disposable masks, but expect that broken and disposable masks will need to be disposed of.

answers.description: This will be especially useful at exits and at recess/gym/sports. They should be obvious, with large enough openings to allow no-contact deposit.
Be prepared for garbage bins to become full more quickly. Also, be sure that those emptying the garbage bins have masks and gloves, as discarded masks are an infection risk.

You can expect that some masks will be discarded outside garbage bins, either on the ground, in hallways, or left on tables or desks. Train your staff to use gloves to pick up any discarded masks, and to avoid touching the mouth and nose covering as much as possible.
